case_vignette: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of chest pain! She describes the pain as intermittent and burning-like! She states that she has tried using proton pump inhibitors but has had no relief of her symptoms! She has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months! Her temperature is 36!7°C (98!1°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg! Examination shows tightness of the skin of the fingers; there are small nonhealing, nonpurulent ulcers over thickened skin on the fingertips! Fine inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases! There is mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium!
question: Which  is most likely associated with her diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing intermittent, burning-like chest pain, weight loss, tightness in the skin of my fingers, and small nonhealing ulcers on my fingertips.
Do you also have any joint pain or stiffness?
No, I do not have any joint pain or stiffness.
Have you noticed any changes in the color of your fingers in response to cold temperatures or stress?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in the color of my fingers in response to cold temperatures or stress.
Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions in the past, or are you currently taking any medications?
I have not mentioned any past medical conditions or current medications.
Is there a family history of autoimmune diseases or any similar symptoms in your family?
I haven't mentioned any family history of autoimmune diseases or similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
